Literature Review: Climate change represents one of the most pressing challenges of our time, necessitating a comprehensive portfolio of economic policies to mitigate its impacts. Theoretical and empirical research underscores the efficacy of carbon pricing and green R&D support as pivotal tools in this endeavor. Carbon pricing, through mechanisms such as carbon taxes or cap-and-trade systems, internalizes the external costs of greenhouse gas emissions, incentivizing reductions in carbon footprints. Empirical studies have demonstrated that carbon pricing can significantly lower emissions without detrimental effects on economic growth, provided it is implemented effectively (Nordhaus, 2019). Green R&D support, on the other hand, fosters innovation in clean technologies, which is crucial for long-term sustainability. Aghion et al. (2016) highlight the importance of public investment in green R&D to overcome market failures and accelerate the transition to a low-carbon economy. However, the implementation of these policies is fraught with challenges. Political resistance, concerns over competitiveness, and the need for international coordination are significant barriers to the adoption of carbon pricing (Stiglitz et al., 2017). Similarly, the allocation of green R&D funds must be carefully managed to ensure that investments yield high-impact innovations (Dechezleprêtre et al., 2019). Beyond carbon pricing and green R&D, a suite of complementary policies is essential to address the multifaceted nature of climate change. Standards and bans, such as those on single-use plastics or inefficient appliances, can drive rapid changes in consumer behavior and industry practices. However, their design and enforcement require careful consideration to avoid unintended consequences and ensure coherence with broader climate objectives (Goulder & Parry, 2008). Targeted subsidies, particularly for renewable energy and energy efficiency, can also play a critical role in accelerating the transition to a low-carbon economy. Yet, the effectiveness of subsidies depends on their design, with poorly targeted subsidies risking inefficiency and fiscal strain (Fischer & Newell, 2008). Carbon border adjustment mechanisms (CBAMs) have emerged as a promising tool to address carbon leakage and level the playing field for domestic industries subject to carbon pricing. By imposing a carbon cost on imports, CBAMs can encourage global emission reductions while protecting the competitiveness of domestic producers (Cosbey et al., 2019). However, the implementation of CBAMs raises complex legal and diplomatic issues, necessitating careful negotiation and design. Climate finance is another critical component of the policy portfolio, enabling the mobilization of resources for mitigation and adaptation efforts in developing countries. The Green Climate Fund and other financial mechanisms play a vital role in supporting vulnerable nations, but the scale of funding remains insufficient to meet the immense needs (Buchner et al., 2019). Moreover, the allocation of climate finance must prioritize projects with the highest potential for emission reductions and resilience building, requiring robust criteria and transparent governance (Nakhooda et al., 2014). In conclusion, combating climate change requires a multifaceted approach that leverages a diverse portfolio of economic policies. Carbon pricing and green R&D support are foundational, but their success hinges on effective implementation and international cooperation. Complementary policies, including standards, bans, targeted subsidies, CBAMs, and climate finance, are essential to address the complex and interconnected challenges of climate change. A coherent and integrated policy framework, underpinned by rigorous research and stakeholder engagement, is crucial to achieving the ambitious goals of the Paris Agreement and securing a sustainable future for all.
